Introduction

The Civil Contingencies Act (2004) identifies the Trust as a Category 1 Responder and imposes a statutory duty on the Trust to carry out risk assessments and to have robust Business Continuity plans in place to manage disruptions to the delivery of service and to have plans for recovery after an event of disruption.
The Business Continuity Policy evaluates the risks which may face the Trust and sets out provisions to eliminate or reduce the highest levels of risk, particularly to critical services.

The Trust must be prepared to respond to any service disruption or emergency that may occur, both internally and/or externally, which threatens the Trusts ability to exercise its civil protection duty as identified by the Civil Contingencies Act (2004). Business continuity planning must be carried out to minimise the effects of a number of potentially disruptive events, for example:
Fire, flood, extreme weather conditions
Loss of utilities, including IT, Power and telephony
Major disruptions to staffing e.g. as a result of an epidemic/pandemic, transport disruption, industrial action, inability to recruit
Major accident or incident, national disaster, terrorist attack
Business continuity management is an important part of the Trust's risk management arrangements.

It is the responsibility of each services Director/Associate Directors and Managers to ensure business continuity plans are reviewed and updated, and that their teams and staff are aware and understand their roles and responsibilities in the event of a business disruption and/or emergency situation.
Scope

The Trusts Business Continuity Policy (BCP) describes how the Trust will respond to an incident that involves either a total loss or partial loss of the hospital site and services. It is not intended to cover the impact of an interruption to or recovery of individual services; this is covered separately by divisional and departmental business continuity plans
The business continuity policy is separate from but can operate alongside the Major Incident Plan and other emergency response plans.
The purpose of this policy is to identify the actions necessary and the resources needed to manage an incident impacting on normal service provision within the Trust, whatever its cause.
Policy objectives:
Identify the risks faced by the Trust (Business Impact Analysis)
Put measures in place to prevent or mitigate impact of the identified risks
Ensure priority clinical and lifesaving services are maintained during the disruption
Outline a recovery plan to ensure all services can be returned to normal practices in a timely manner within acceptable timeframe (Recovery Plan).
The policy will ensure:
Trust contingency arrangements and procedures regarding incidents are implemented
The safety of staff, patients and visitors
Timely and suitable responses to disruptive incident and/or threat to the wellbeing of staff, patients and visitors. Business continuity requirements are quickly identified and implemented
People, physical, financial and information assets of the Trust are protected
Sufficient resources are identified and made available
The management of the crisis is reviewed after the event to ensure lessons for improvements are identified and implemented and shared where appropriate.
Publication and distribution

The Civil Contingencies Act 2004 allows Category 1 responders to restrict the publication of plans and prohibit the publication of sensitive information and personal data. It advises publication only where there is a positive benefit in doing so or where the public interest in disclosure fails to outweigh the interests of the organisation. This plan contains key information for use by Trust staff in business continuity incidents and it would not be in the interest of the Trust to publish it in full for the benefit of the general public. Distribution of the full information contained within this plan will therefore be restricted to Trust staff that may be responsible for responding to business continuity incidents only.
A copy of this policy and individual service plans, and action cards are available in hard copy format and electronically on each sites intranet.

Individual services are responsible for ensuring that hard copies of individual service BCPs and action cards are available in their service area, divisions and departments.  Service  leads  are  responsible  for raising awareness of the location of  business continuity and action cards both on the hub and within their service.

To fulfil relevant legal and contractual EPRR requirement, including the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 and Health and Social Care act 2012, and ensure a robust and sustainable 24/7 response to emergencies.
5.1.2 Provide the resilience to manage emergencies and incidents that affect any MSEFT site, with escalation where necessary.

5.1.5 Ensure preparedness to maintain critical services in periods of disruption.

Under the Civil Contingencies Act, the Trust is classified as a “Category 1Responder”. And subject to the full set of civil protection duties, other category 1 responder's include Local Authorities, government agencies, emergency services: Fire, Police, Ambulance and other NHS bodies.
Category 1 responders are required to:
Assess local risks and use this to inform emergency planning
Put in place emergency plans
Put in place business continuity management arrangements
Put in place arrangements to make information available to the public about civil protection matters and maintain arrangements to warn, inform and advise the public in the event of any emergency
Share information with other local responders to enhance co- ordination
Co-operate with other local responders to enhance co-ordination and efficiency
Provide advice and assistance to businesses and voluntary organisations about business continuity management (Local Authorities only)

requirements, of which the following objectives and outcomes apply:

Site Emergency Preparedness and Resilience Groups: The role of these groups is to ensure that the Trust's business continuity and emergency response plans are consistent with all national and local legislation requirements. The group membership assures Trust Board that there is an effective system of management to ensure that the Trust is compliant with the NHS England and NHS Improvement
Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR) Framework and Core Standards.
6.1.1  The key tasks of the group are:

To develop, monitor, test, evaluate and review the Trust's plans for major incidents and business continuity, ensuring plans are robust and consistent will all Government and local planning guides, risk assessments and duties of care.

To develop and oversee implementation of a series of training programmes relevant to each staffing level, to run throughout the year and to report compliance with the care Quality Commission Regulations.
To ensure that the Trust meets its full requirements as a category 1 responder according to the Civil Contingencies Act (2004) and NHS England / NHS Improvement EPRR Framework.
To create plans against a timetable to ensure that all areas within the Trust are operationally ready to respond to any major incident event.
To oversee the implementation of any recommendations, if required, following a test or a Major Incident.
To endorse joint planning documents including Mutual Aid.
To provide direction for the development of Trust Continuity plans to ensure individual services have a coordinated response to major incidents.
External resilience groups and forums Essex Resilience Forum (ERF)

The Civil Contingencies Act 2004 requires local responder bodies to co-operate in preparing for and responding to emergencies through a local Resilience Forum (LRF). Essex has always recognised the  importance of multi- agency working and now operates under the Essex Resilience Forum (ERF).
Essex Local Health Resilience Partnership (LHRP) (Strategic and Operational) Groups

The Local Health Resilience Partnership (LHRP) is a forum for organisations in the local health sector (including private and voluntary sector where appropriate). The LHRP facilitates health sector preparedness and planning for emergencies at Local Resilience Forum (LRF) level. It supports the NHS, Public Health England (PHE) and local authority (LA) representatives on the ERF in their role to represent health sector Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR).
ERF Risk Planning Meeting is a multi-agency group. The main purpose of the group is to review the Community Risk Register and identify any new emerging risks and training needs.
Group and Individual responsibilities within the Trust are as follows:
6.3.1 Trust Board will be responsible for:
Ensuring appropriate structures are in place to implement effective business continuity management arrangements;
Monitoring and reviewing of the Business Continuity Procedure and Trust Business Continuity Plan;
Committing resources necessary to adequately control identified business continuity risks.

6.3.2 Chief Executive / Deputy Chief Executive has overall responsibility under the Civil Contingencies Act rests with the Chief Executive to ensure that the Trust has adequate emergency and business continuity plans in place at Trust level this is delegated to the Deputy Chief Executive as the lead executive and senior responsible officer (SRO) for Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response across the Trust.
6.3.3 Chief Operating Officer is the nominated executive director and is responsible for ensuring that:
Plans are in place to manage disruptions to services – internal or external that requires special provision to be made.
Plans are written and published to ensure business continuity for any emergencies that may impact on Trust activity.
Business continuity plans are kept up to date.
The Trust is compliant with all legislation relevant to EPRR.
The plans are exercised appropriately.
Trust staff are familiar with the plans for their particular work area and are familiar with the Trust's core plan.
There is participation in multi-agency planning and exercising.
An annual report is produced for the Trust Board.
The Trust's activity with regard to EPRR meets the requirements of the NHS England / NHS Improvement EPRR core standards and Care Quality Commission Standards.

6.3.4 Managing Director on each site is responsible for ensuring Trust wide policies and procedures are established within each hospital location. The Managing Director (or nominated deputy) would usually lead the site's response and represent the site on MSEFT incident response teleconferences.

6.3.5 Executive Directors will take leadership of their business continuity arrangements and are responsible for maintaining their individual services, and for alerting the need to activate Business Continuity Plans if such an event occurs with their directorate. They will promote a culture of business continuity within the Trust

6.3.6 Senior Responsible Officer (SRO) will have overall responsibility for Business Continuity Management within the Trust and be responsible, on behalf of the Trust Board, for ensuring the implementation of the Business Continuity Plan.
The Senior Responsible Officer has specific responsibility for ensuring that:
A business continuity culture is embedded within the organisation;
Trust Board is kept fully informed of significant business continuity risks;
Financial resources are made available through the business planning process, in support of perceived high risks
The Trust has co-ordinated arrangements in place centrally recorded in the form of a production of the Trust Business Continuity Plan; and
An emergency planning and business continuity lead is identified.

6.3.7 Head of Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR) is responsible for overseeing the implementation of the Trusts business continuity management system (BCMS), and for providing assurance of this system as part of the annual EPRR core standards process. They will provide advice, guidance and support to directors and managers throughout any incident impacting on business continuity. The Head of EPRR will ensure that appropriate representation is maintained at the Local Health Resilience Forum (LHRP), for the purposes of sharing best practice and gaining assurance of system-wide business continuity

6.3.8 Directors of Operations /Heads of Service are responsible for ensuring that appropriate business continuity plans are developed and maintained to meet the requirements of the CCA in relation to their service. He/she must ensure such plans are consistent with the overall Trust Corporate Business Continuity Plan. They are also responsible for:
Ensuring the Business continuity policy is actioned within their care group, and retain ownership and responsibility for the plans within their areas.
Ensuring that a Business Impact Analysis (BIA) is developed for each service.
Carrying out a risk assessment for each critical function identified.
Updating the plans when any changes in service, staff, supplies or equipment are undertaken.
Ensuring hard copies of the BCP and action cards are available within departments.
A critical function analysis and action cards are reviewed annually
Ensuring that all relevant staff are clear and have briefed in the use of the plans.

6.3.9 All Managers will take ownership of their business continuity arrangements and are responsible for ensuring that appropriate business continuity plans are developed and maintained to meet the requirements of the CCA in relation to their Division/Directorate or Department. He/she must ensure such plans are consistent with the overall Trust Business Continuity Plan. They are also responsible for:
Ensuring that a Business Impact Analysis (BIA) is developed for each service.
Carrying out a risk assessment for each critical function identified.
Updating the plans when any changes in service, staff, supplies or equipment are undertaken.
Ensuring hard copies of the BCP and action cards are available within departments.
Annually reviewing the plans
Ensuring that all relevant staff are clear and have briefed in the use of the plans.

data.text: Types of incidents

For the NHS, incidents are classed as business continuity incident, critical incident and major incident. Each will impact upon the service delivery within the NHS and require contingency plans to be implemented. NHS organisations should be confident of the severity of any incident that may warrant a major incident declaration, particularly where this may be due to internal capacity pressures, if a critical incident has not been raised previously through the appropriate local escalation procedure.
Business continuity incident

A business continuity incident is an event or occurrence that disrupts, or might disrupt, an organisation's normal service delivery, below acceptable predefined levels, where special arrangements need to be implemented until services can return to an acceptable level. (This could be a surge in demand requiring resources to be temporarily redeployed).
Critical Incident

A critical incident is any localised incident where the level of disruption results in the organisation temporarily or permanently losing its ability to deliver critical services. For example, patients may have been harmed or the environment is not safe requiring special measures and support from other agencies, to restore normal operating functions.
Major Incident

A major incident is any occurrence that presents serious threat to the health of the community or causes such numbers or types of casualties, as to require special arrangements to be implemented. For the NHS this will include any event defined as an emergency.
Business impact analysis (BIA)

As part of the Business Continuity process, a business impact analysis (BIA) is required to be carried out to identify the risks of a potential disaster occurring and the subsequent impact of a business interruption. Minor business interruptions occur on a daily basis and are dealt with using normal services and resources.

The BIA is intended to provide a tool for each Division/department to identify its critical functions, assessing the impacts that might result from an incident and the levels of resources and time required for recovery. Subsequently, critical services and priorities for recovery are identified.
Key risks to the critical functions, which would result in the loss of function, should be identified and documented in the BIA.

The development of alternative service delivery strategies and plans prior to an incident occurring will inform the Trust's response and actions to be taken to maintain appropriate levels of service should the risk materialise.
The risk assessment process will be used to analyse:
Critical functions
Dependencies required delivering these activities. These may be internal or external.
The impact of the disruption on these activities, including financial consequences.
Specialist advice
Internal and external communication requirements
The timescales for recovery – Recovery Time Objectives (RTO)
Recovery profile, e.g. resources, equipment, staffing, space, etc.
Recovery options
Training needs
Testing and monitoring provisions
Business Continuity and Recovery Plans will be produced for all risks identified. Copies of all plans will be available on the Trust's intranet.
Risk assessments

Risk assessments are regularly carried out as a part of the Trust's daily business. In relation to business continuity management, a risk assessment looks at the probability and impact of specific threats that could cause disruption to the delivery of services. Threats in this context refer to issues that have the capability of impacting on the ability of the trust to deliver its services and therefore place patients at risk.

The assessment of threats is not intended to be comprehensive but a pragmatic view of events that would either prevent services from operating as normal, or, place patients at risk from services that would be interrupted.

The Trust's approach to assessing threats for the purpose of continuity management plans is to identify in advance key threats and key alternatives to service provision, including during the contracting process. However, actual events may not exactly match what has been anticipated. Recognising the complex nature of the trust and the skills of its staff, the Trust will construct a strategic and/or Tactical incident management team of the right managers and staff  that will address the potential consequences of threats and put in place alternative arrangements, dynamically – according to the specific nature of the threat or incident that emerges at the time.

data.text: Criticality

‘Criticality' has a particular definition in the context of business continuity. It is for the organisation itself to determine which of its functions are critical. It is not expected that all critical functions that operate in MSEFT should continue to deliver all functions at ordinary levels in the event of an emergency; some critical functions may need to be scaled up, while others may need to be scaled down or suspended. Critical functions could be viewed as those that fulfil or impact on, emergency management/civil protection, human welfare, the environment and security, or those with legal, financial or reputational implications.

Business continuity plans

Each Division / Directorate is required to have a business continuity plan that is developed using the information contained within the service BIA's. It is important that each Division/department has ownership of the business continuity plans that relate to the services it provides, and ensures that each services critical functions are included that identifies the risks to those functions.
Plans should be cascaded to all staff within Divisions as appropriate, ensuring that staff are made aware of the Business Continuity Plan for their service, and how the plan is implemented.
Original copies of the BIA and business continuity plans will be held by each Division. A copy of the BIA and Business Continuity Plan should be sent to EPRR leads.

The impact of any incident on the Trust will be determined by the time, nature and duration. The decision to implement the Business Continuity Plan(s) will be the made by the most senior person on duty at the time of the incident.
Contracted services

12.5.1 Services provided to the Trust by external suppliers should have business continuity arrangements in place. In the development or review of contracts and service level agreements, provision for business continuity arrangements should be considered. For ease of reference the following standardised wording should be included:

12.5.2 “The supplier or contractor should have business continuity arrangements in place which provides details on how the organisation will respond to and recover from a significant disruptive incident that seriously impacts upon the organisation's ability to provide the contracted service or product.
12.5.3 In the event to a disruption impacting on the supplier or contractors
ability to provide a service or product to the organisation, then advice on alternative products or suppliers should be provided.
Activation, command and control

All individual service Business Continuity Plans highlight who to escalate issues to. This will usually be a senior manager within the division and also the site Manager. If the issue is serious or affects more than one area the On-Call Manager and Executive Director On- Call will be notified.

If required they will implement a Trust Recovery Team. The Executive Director On-Call will become Strategic (Gold) Commander and the Director On-Call will assume the role of Hospital tactical (Silver) Commander. The Divisional Managers will be at the Operational (Bronze) response level reporting issues for their divisions to the Hospital Silver. The purpose of the Trust Recovery Team is to coordinate business continuity activities and plan for a return to normality.
Command and control

The Director making the decision to enact the BCP will immediately convene a Strategic Leadership Team (SLT). This team will undertake an initial assessment of the situation and take overall responsibility for managing the Trust response to the incident. If necessary, the SLT will mobilise the Incident Control Team to co-ordinate the frontline response to the incident. In a severe incident where a large proportion of the site is affected, the SLT will need to decide if the Trust can continue to operate.
Strategic (gold) leadership team (SLT)
The Strategic Leadership Team (SLT) will take the pivotal role in the enactment of the BCP. The team will:
Decide whether the full BCP needs enacting
Lead the overall response to the incident in order to maintain health and safety and first priority services
Establish an Incident Command Centre
Mobilise a Tactical (Silver) Incident Control Team as necessary
Take reports from the Incident Control Team and where necessary direct their actions
Inform and liaise with external stakeholders (e.g. NHS England and CCG)
Agree a communication plan and approve all information released to the press
Maintain an accurate event log
Decide when the Trust can stand down from the BCP
Tactical (silver) incident control team
The Tactical Incident Control Team will co-ordinate actions at a Tactical level. The Tactical Incident Response Team will:-
Co-ordinate frontline management of the incident
Make an accurate assessment of the impact of the incident and its likely duration
Ensure the safety of staff, patients and visitors on site
Act as the main point of contact with the emergency services
Ensure that the Strategic Leadership Team is kept fully up to date and given sufficient information on which to base decisions
Implement Strategic Leadership Team instructions
Direct and support local teams
Operational (clinical) response teams

Operational Response Teams are the staff on the ground dealing with an incident. The primary responsibility of the local teams will be to ensure the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors. They will advise the Operational Response Team of the practicability of maintaining their service and identify the resources necessary to achieve this.
Out of hours response

13.7.1 Outside normal working hours the Strategic and Tactical Response Teams will be amalgamated until either sufficient staff are on site or normal hours resume. The Clinical Site Manager and/or Duty Sister (Medicine and Surgery) will assume initial control until relieved by a more senior manager.
13.7.2 Incident Management Personnel will be expected to attend the hospital as soon as reasonably practicable.

formed as an Incident Coordination Centre Management Team.

13.8.3 One of the key functions of the Trust Recovery Team is to coordinate the prioritisation of staff, physical space and equipment when the incident is affecting a large proportion of the trust. Training requirements

EPRR leads will annually set out the Emergency planning and resilience exercise and training programme which will detail all training available internally, externally and via multi-agency partners and exercises scheduled for the year.

The programme will contain a mix of formal and informal training sessions, remaining flexible and able to adapt to the changing risks, priorities and needs of the organisation and be carried out by competent persons.

EPRR leads will provide bespoke training and exercises upon request, where possible, and will advertise relevant training to appropriate teams and individuals, whilst retaining records of sessions and delegates
Exercising and review
The Divisions must ensure all their business continuity plans are exercised on an annual basis unless they have a real activation of the plan following an incident.
An action plan should be produced including lessons identified that require an update of the plan and other issues which have been identified which require further actions.
These action plans should be reported through the EPRR Committee to enable other Divisions to learn from their exercises or incidents
The exercising of plans is also a requirement of ISO 22301:2019 which states:

An organisation's business continuity and incident management arrangements cannot be considered reliable until exercised and unless their currency is maintained. Exercising is essential to developing teamwork, competence, confidence and knowledge which is vital at the time of an incident. Arrangements should be verified through exercising, audit and self-assessment processes to ensure that they are fit-for-purpose1.
Exercises will be provided and completed to ensure staff are familiarised with the Trust and Service plans.
An exercise will be carried out annually to test the response outlined in the business continuity policy and supporting service plans.
Following any exercise or live incident, this plan and any service specific plans will be reviewed and revised in light of any lessons learned

Divisions / departments should schedule and diarized when their BCP is to be tested, EPRR leads should also be advised of the date for the test to be undertaken and be provided with evidence of completion.

data.text: Internal audit

The Trust's EPRR leads will carry out an audit of service Business Impact Analysis (BIA) and business continuity plans (BCPs) at planned intervals with Divisions / Directorates. Plans should be submitted to the EPRR leads before the required review date in order that any non-conformances can be identified and corrected within the required timeframe.
Any non-conforming findings shall be documented and subsequent corrective actions implemented.
The internal audit will consist of the following objectives:
A business continuity management plan is in place and subject to regular review.
An Impact analysis and Risk Assessment has been carried out is subject to regular review.
An inventory of network, resource requirements and staffing numbers has been drawn up and is subject to regular review.
Up to date training records confirm that all relevant training has been received (where required).
Documentation relating to all critical systems is in place and subject to regular review.
There is assurance that all contractors providing services have adequate contingency arrangements.
Emergency procedures are in place with all contact details updated when appropriate.
Tests are carried out routinely on all areas of the Business Continuity Plan, are subject to review and where appropriate changes implemented.
Improving the BCMS

Troubleshooting problems and attempting to identify and prevent potential problems is an essential in ensuring the Trust continues to provide services to patients and the community. Problems have a financial impact on the Trust. The ability to correct existing problems or implement controls to prevent potential problems is essential for continued delivery of patient care and provides an efficient delivery of services Trust wide. This process and the actions required are often impacted due to inadequate documentation of the actions taken. Properly documented actions provide important historical data for identifying potential problems and lessons learnt, and improvement to the business continuity plan and processes.

In order for the BCMS to be effective when incidents occur or nonconformities are identified, the following process for completing and documenting corrective or preventative actions should be followed. The result will be a complete, well documented investigation and solution that will satisfy regulatory requirements and form the basis for an effective continuous improvement business continuity plan(s) for the Trust.
Corrective and preventative action plan (CPAP)

CAPA focuses on the systematic investigation of discrepancies (failures and/or deviations) in an attempt to prevent their recurrence (for Corrective Action) or prevent from occurrence (for Preventative Action). To ensure that Corrective Actions and preventative Actions are effective, the systematic investigation of failure incidence is pivotal in identifying the Corrective Actions and Preventative Actions undertaken. CAPA is part of the overall Management System.

CAPA shall be used to identify, correct and eliminate the cause of potential and actual non-conformance, minimising the risk of poor quality and providing continuous improvement. When a discrepancy arises, through scheduled audits, information security reviews, feedback and from other non-conformities identified through the Steering Group, the Corrective and Preventative Action Plan (CAPA) template shall be used.
Preventive action
16.6.1 A preventative action is a process for detecting potential problems or non- conformances' and eliminating them. The process includes:
Identify the potential problem or non-conformance
Find the cause of the potential problem
Develop a plan to prevent the occurrence.
Implement the plan
16.6.2 Review the actions taken and the effectiveness in preventing the problem.

16.6.3 Through the membership of the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Steering Group, the group shall identify and record, via the corrective and preventative action plan template, any potential nonconformities and the necessary action to eliminate their cause and avoid occurrence.
Corrective action
A corrective action is a term that encompasses the process of reacting to equipment failures, system failures or other nonconformities within the BCMS and correcting them. The process includes:
Reviewing or defining the problem or nonconformity
Finding the cause of the problem
Develop a plan to correct the problem and prevent a recurrence
Implementing the plan
Continual improvement

Through the setting and monitoring of the objectives, continued BCMS development by the steering group, and acting upon problems and outcomes of exercises and incidents, the Trust shall endeavour to continual improve the effectiveness of the Business Continuity Management System.
Management review of the BCMS

The Management review of the Trusts BCMS will be undertaking by members of the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Steering Group. Senior Management shall review every two years, or when significant changes occur, to ensure its continuing suitability, adequacy and effectiveness.
The review shall include assessing opportunities for improvement and the need for changes to the BCMS, including the business continuity management policy and management objectives.

The results of the reviews will be clearly documented and records maintained. Results of the review will be communicated to the membership of the steering group for further circulation and communication to divisions and departments.
Review input agenda (input to the review shall include information on):
Results of BCMS audits and reviews, including where appropriate those of key suppliers and stakeholders;
Status of preventive and corrective actions;
Level of residual risk and acceptable risk;
Vulnerabilities or threats not adequately address in the previous risk assessment;
Follow-up actions from previous management reviews;
Any internal or external changes that could affect the BCMS;
Recommendations for improvement;
Exercise results;
Emerging good practice and guidance;
Lessons from incidents; and
Results of training and awareness programmes.
Review output (output shall include any decisions and actions related to): A Formal Review of the BCMS Scope, Police and Objective(s)
Varying the scope of the BCMS;
Improving the effectiveness of the BCMS;
Modification of BCM strategy and procedures, as necessary, to respond to internal and external events that could impact on the BCMS, including changes to:
Resource needs; and
Funding and budget requirements.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local incident management plans and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform members of the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Dissemination and implementation
Staff groups that need to have knowledge of the policy:
Chief Executive
Deputy Chief Executive / Accountable Executive Officer for EPRR
Chief Operating Officer (COO)
Executive Directors and Divisional Managers
Divisional Business Continuity Planning Leads
All managers and senior nurses
Key objectives:
EPRR Committee meet at least quarterly.
Business Continuity Plan is reviewed annually or after a significant event.
Service business continuity plans are reviewed annually and following any live activation.
The divisions must ensure all their business continuity plans are exercised on an annual basis unless they have a real activation of the plan.
Business continuity is referred to in corporate induction.
Divisional Managers ensure that the Business Continuity Plans for their staff is embedded to ensure they are aware of its contents.
Records of who has been trained and exercised in the plan must be maintained by the Divisions.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 3: Action card for Trust incident recovery lead
TRUST INCIDENT RECOVERY LEAD ACTION CARD

table_items.text: To lead the Trusts response to the incident and support the Strategic (Gold) Commanders decision making. The Trust Recovery Team is responsible for analysing the overall impact of an incident on staff, patients and services, ensuring that the Trust response is proportionate and planning the return to normality. The team once formed will agree a recovery strategy and initial operating timeframe. The team will cover the following areas:

Where the incident involves loss of premises, identify the areas requesting relocation and based on the critical activities and environment required decided on who will be relocated to which area Revise bed management policy based on the incident. Review/revise Infection, Prevention and Control guidelines. Cancel elective activity with a plan for to re-instate where possible

Liaise with Divisional Managers who will be acting as Operational (Bronze) Commanders. If decision taken, inform operational commanders of the decision to cancel elective activity. Liaise with CCG around services that need to be suspended. Request suspension of targets and decide on the triggers for re-introduction.
Request mutual aid through the CCG (where required from within Essex). If required from outside of Essex this is likely to be referred to the NHS England/Improvement Regional Team – East of England.

Where the incident involves loss of critical staff coordinate redeployment of staff from other areas based on the areas critical activities and skill mix needed. Formally recognise the efforts of all staff and volunteers once the incident is over.

During the incident, and the immediate period afterwards it is reasonable for non-critical services to have been temporarily suspended so that resources can be reallocated to the more critical areas. However, these functions cannot be suspended indefinitely. Services should have been discontinued in a priority order with the most important functions being discontinued last. The recovery order will, in the main, be a reversal of this. The Business Impact Assessment highlights the most and least critical functions for each Division. These will be overseen by the Trust Recovery Team who will make the final decision on the order of recovery after taking advice from all affected Divisions. The Trust may have to increase funding in areas which were suspended. These areas could have increased waiting lists where, for example, elective surgery was postponed. Additionally, it should be expected that some patients will have developed complications as a result of delay. Seek financial redress where appropriate. It should not be expected that the organisation will be able to recover quickly from any event.

In conjunction with the Communications Lead, provide up to date information to the public, patients and staff. Communicate the concept of “new normal” i.e. daily activity will not return to baseline until the incident and its effects are truly resolved. Communicate the recovery strategy, what to expect, announcements and notifications of the gradual restoration of services.
Be prepared to deal with press enquiries that have resulted from the incident. Acknowledge contributions of staff.

Review and ensure that appropriate levels of supplies and equipment are maintained during the incident. Determine any equipment which has been lost or destroyed which would need replacement to allow restoration of service. Arrange for the cleaning and decontamination of equipment to an appropriate standard if necessary.
COLLATION OF EVIDENCE ACTIONS – ALL PAPERWORK SUBJECT TO DISCLOSURE
Collate any paperwork used (even scraps of paper) and hand to the Emergency Planning Lead.
Sign-off the Emergency Log Book with the Loggist.
Ensure the debrief feedback form (Appendix 2) is widely distributed to those involved for completion.
Make arrangements for a formal debrief to take place.
